crypto.name: Breaching the crime Scene
crypto.desc:
The police is investigating a suspicious web forum. They cannot find a way to access it though --- its protected with a password. Luckily, they've managed to set up a packet sniffer between the server and one of its microservices. Unluckily, the traffic is encrypted. Can you help them out?
Connection info:

After starting an instance, use sc to bind it to the port on your machine:

For the web service:

sc -b 5000 <instance_subdomain.instance_domain>

For the packet sniffer:

sc -b 8888 tcp-<instance_subdomain.instance_domain>

You can then connect to the web service on https://localhost:5000 and to the packet sniffer nc localhost 8888. The web server uses a cert signed by the CA in the ca.crt file. It is included for your convenience.

crypto.name: backup
crypto.desc: Can you store the flag for me? k thx

crypto.name: i made the otp
crypto.desc:
I made the OTP!

Look mommy, I made an unbreakable cipher! It was so simple.

crypto.name: leaky prime
crypto.desc: To show you the power of Flex Tape I cut a fragment of the prime! The question is - can you fix it?

crypto.name: letter
crypto.desc: Bob has been missing for a while. We've found an encrypted letter from Alice to Derek, along with some encryption software. Maybe it contains a clue?

forensic.name: BTS Antivirus
forensic.desc: I realised that something was wrong with that free flag document, so I decided to download an antivirus. It worked well - maybe too well, because it seems to have encrypted all my files. I don't really know how to feel about that - maybe it's for security. I've captured internet traffic and created a memory dump of the antivirus process. Can you analyze what it really did?

forensic.name: Free flag
forensic.desc:
Omg, a document with a free flag inside!

Pros:

    Free flag

Cons:

    I think someone just logged in to my computer

misc.name: object dec
misc.desc:
Object dec

We managed to intercept what we reckon is a poorly encrypted json containing caesar hacker group member target credentials. Come on, pwn, there is a flag in there: rlW1p2IlozSgMFV6VaOupTS5LGVkZmpvYPNvpTSmp3qipzDvBvNvDaEGD1ETr3xjqI9lZmZmoUysL3WeMS90nQAsLmDmpmElsFW9sd

pwn.name: Chroot Escape
pwn.desc:
Our new awesome / does not have /bin :P
connection info:

    Download snicat https://github.com/CTFd/snicat

pwn.name: shellcode
pwn.desc: Reading and writing are not allowed to prevent flag leaking

rev.name: Back to the future
rev.desc: Values are traveling to the future.

rev.name: Little Rusty
rev.desc:
I've heard you like computers.

So I put a computer in a computer for you.

I tried running it but it seem to have gotten stuck.

Can you fix it for me?

rev.name: Login Page
rev.desc: There are rumors that admin can view the flag.

rev.name: Logs
rev.desc: Our lazy engineer did not remove debug logs from the application. Hopefully it will not leak any sensitive data. usage: ./bin run

rev.name: No Logs
rev.desc: The engineers have been told that they should remove excessive logging because additional information helps reverse engineers. In our latest release the logs have been removed. usage: ./bin run

steg.name: rolling in the rick
steg.desc:
POV: You are on a camping trip listening to a great song.

credits: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=dQw4w9WgXcQ

PS: The mosquito has something to tell you.

steg.name: walls
steg.desc:
i am in your walls

Note from the author: You don't have to bruteforce anything or use some specific programs for data extraction (like steghide for example) to solve this challenge. I also suggest that you take a look at this.

web.name: Token auth
web.desc: JWT is very common way to handle authorization. It has to be secure.

web.name: config
web.desc: Configuration is tough. Sometimes things don't go as planned.
